sen.j: 湯浅 宗重（ゆあさ むねしげ、生没年不詳）は、平安時代末期から鎌倉時代初期の武将。
sen.e: Muneshige YUASA (years of birth and death unknown) is a busho (Japanese military commander) over the end of the Heian Era and the early period of the Kamakura Era.

sen.j: 藤原北家流藤原宗永の子とされる（諸説あり）。
sen.e: He is believed to be a son of FUJIWARA no Munenaga from the Fujiwara north family (there are various theories).
He is believed to be a son of FUJIWARA no Munenaga from the Northern House of Fujiwara clan (there are various theories).

sen.j: 紀伊国湯浅城（現・和歌山県有田郡湯浅町青木）主。
sen.e: The lord of Yuasa-jo Castle, Kii Province (present-day Aoki, Yuasa-cho, Arita-gun, Wakayama Prefecture).
The lord of Yuasa-jo Castle, Kii Province (present-day Aoki, Yuasa-cho, Arita-gun, Wakayama Prefecture).

sen.j: 康治2年（1143年）、所領である紀伊国有田郡湯浅荘に湯浅城を築いて、今まで居城であった広保山城から移る。
sen.e: In 1143, he built Yuasa-jo Castle in his Shoryo (territory), Yuasa-sho Manor, Arita district, Kii province, and moved to the castle from 広保山城, where he lived before.

sen.cmt: Shoryo削除し、his territoryとしました。District, Province 大文字にしました。広保山城→Hirohoyama-jo Castle [http://www.geocities.jp/jyousekiroku/kinki/wakayama/arida.htm]

sen.j: 平治元年（1159年）、熊野詣で紀伊国に来ていた平清盛と共に上洛を果たして有力武将の一人となる。
sen.e: In 1159, he went to the capital (Kyoto) together with TAIRA no Kiyomori, who visited Kii province for pilgrimages to Kumano Sanzan, and he became one of the powerful military commanders.

sen.j: 清盛の死後、平重盛の子平忠房を擁して湯浅城に立て籠もるが源頼朝に降伏し、文治2年（1186年）に所領を安堵される。
sen.e: After the death of Kiyomori, he held up in Yuasa-jo Castle to support TAIRA no Tadafusa, a son of TAIRA no Kiyomori, but he surrendered to MINAMOTO no Yoritomo and was provided with the authorization for land ownership in 1186.

sen.j: 以後、順調に所領を増やして紀の川流域まで勢力を広げ、後に湯浅党と呼ばれた。
sen.e: Since then, he steadily expanded his Shoryo up to the area along the course of Kino-kawa River, and he was later called Yuasa-to (Yuasa party).

sen.j: 湯浅氏は戦国時代 (日本)に至り、毛利氏に属して萩藩士となったという。
sen.e: It is said that the Yuasa clan served under the Mori clan in the Sengoku period (period of warring states) (in Japan) and became a feudal retainer of Hagi.
